title: Liverpool Said To Have Begun Coaching Reshuffle
text:
Liverpool Said To Have Begun Coaching Reshuffle 13:35, UK, Thursday 08 October 2015 Share by email Gary McAllister will leave his role as Liverpool's first-team coach, according to Sky sources. 
The former Reds midfielder and Scotland international is now believed to be considering another coaching position within the club. 
With Jurgen Klopp set to take over as Liverpool's new manager in the coming days, McAllister is thought to be just one of a number of casualties at Anfield. 
Sean O'Driscoll, who was assistant manager under Brendan Rodgers, will leave the club, along with Glenn Driscoll (head of performance), and Chris Davies (head of opposition analysis). 
However, Pep Ljinders will remain as part of the first-team coaching set up and it is understood that McAllister took training on Thursday despite hearing the news that he will not be retained in his current position. 
Liverpool would not confirm any of these reported changes. 
Klopp is expected to travel to Merseyside on Thursday afternoon ahead of his imminent appointment as Liverpool manager. 
Klopp, who led Borussia Dortmand to two German league titles in his seven years at the club, has spoken personally to the club's American owner, Fenway Sports Group, and those talks have now reached an advanced stage. 
Sky Sports News reporter Vinny O'Connor said: "We're still waiting for the finer details to be sorted out. Jurgen Klopp has told the Liverpool owners that he does want the job but those finer details could still hold things up. 
"There has been no definite hold-up, but we do know that Jurgen Klopp has been booked into accommodation here for the next two nights. 
"Both parties will be hoping those finer details can be sorted out in the next few hours - we're not necessarily expecting an announcement today, but Liverpool are edging closer." 
Rodgers was sacked on Sunday following the 1-1 draw at Everton. Promoted Stories
